revision.text:
[[File:Bromham Lake 6.JPG|thumb|[[Bromham Lake]]|350px|alt=Bromham Lake]] [[Bedfordshire]] is a county in the [[East of England]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/beginner-s-guide/eurostat/east-of-england/index.html|title=East of England|publisher=Office for National Statistics|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113165155/http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/beginner-s-guide/eurostat/east-of-england/index.html|archivedate=13 January 2016|df=}} It is bounded by [[Hertfordshire]] to the south-east, [[Cambridgeshire]] to the north-east, [[Northamptonshire]] to the north, and [[Buckinghamshire]] to the west.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesinengland.com/|title=Your Guide to the Counties of England|publisher=Counties in England|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010173247/http://www.countiesinengland.com/|archivedate=10 October 2016|df=}} It has an area of {{convert|1235 |sqkm|sqmi}}, and a population estimated in 2016 at 640,000, with an increase of 11% over the previous ten years.{{cite web|url=https://www.justiceinspectorates.gov.uk/hmic/bedfordshire/|title=Bedfordshire Police|publisher=Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary|accessdate=6 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062903/https://www.justiceinspectorates.gov.uk/hmic/bedfordshire/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} Geographically, it is mainly rural, but still the [[List of ceremonial counties of England|fourteenth most densely populated county]] of England, with over half the population living in the two largest built-up areas, [[Luton]] and [[Bedford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.centralbedfordshire.gov.uk/Images/Bedfordshire%20Hate%20Crime%20Strategy%20-%20final%20May%202014_tcm6-54651.pdf|page=6|title=Bedfordshire Hate Crime Strategy|publisher=Central Bedfordshire Council et al|accessdate=3 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304025458/http://www.centralbedfordshire.gov.uk/Images/Bedfordshire%20Hate%20Crime%20Strategy%20-%20final%20May%202014_tcm6-54651.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} The county is governed by three [[Unitary authorities of England|unitary authorities]], [[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]], [[Central Bedfordshire]] and Luton.{{cite web|url=http://www.bedfordshire.gov.uk/CommunityAndLiving/ArchivesAndRecordOffice/pdfs/Archives_2014-15_annual_report.pdf|title=Bedfordshire & Luton Archives & Records Service Annual Report, 2014/15|publisher=Bedfordshire & Luton Archives & Records Service|accessdate=3 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304050629/http://www.bedfordshire.gov.uk/CommunityAndLiving/ArchivesAndRecordOffice/pdfs/Archives_2014-15_annual_report.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} The county town is Bedford, and the name is first recorded in the [[Treaty of Alfred and Guthrum|treaty]] in about 879 between King [[Alfred the Great]] and [[Guthrum]], which divided English and Danish territory by a line which went through Bedford.{{cite book|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/beds/vol3/pp1-9#fnn5|title=A History of the County of Bedford|volume=3|page=1|editor-first=William|editor-last=Page|year=1912|publisher=Victoria County History|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402160115/http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/beds/vol3/pp1-9#fnn5|archivedate=2015-04-02|df=}} Much of Luton and southern Bedfordshire lies in the [[Chilterns]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]].{{cite web|url=http://www.centralbedfordshire.gov.uk/Images/South%20Bedfordshire%20Green%20Infrastructure%20plan_tcm6-8582.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120830082722/http://www.centralbedfordshire.gov.uk/Images/South%20Bedfordshire%20Green%20Infrastructure%20plan_tcm6-8582.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 August 2012|page=9|title=Luton and southern Bedfordshire Green Infrastructure Plan|publisher=Greensand Trust|year=2009|accessdate=6 March 2016}} North and mid Bedfordshire are undulating claylands with broad river valleys of the [[River Great Ouse]] and its tributaries, and the [[Bedfordshire Greensand Ridge]]. [[Jurassic]] and [[Cretaceous]] clays are overlaid by [[Quaternary]] glacial deposits of chalky boulder clay.{{cite web|url=http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/file/4984544973291520|title=Bedfordshire and Cambridgeshire Claylands|series=National Character Area profile|number=88|pages=11, 40|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=10 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211130845/http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/file/4984544973291520|archivedate=11 December 2015|df=}} [[Local Nature Reserve]]s (LNRs) are designated by local authorities under the [[National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949]]. The local authority must have a legal control over the site, by owning or leasing it, or having a legal agreement with the owner. LNRs are sites which have a special local interest either biologically or geologically, and local authorities have a duty to care for them. They can apply local [[Byelaws in the United Kingdom|bye-laws]] to manage and protect LNRs.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|title=Protected or designated areas|date=9 April 2013|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504145328/https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|title=Local nature reserves: setting up and management|date=2 October 2014|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704111109/https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|archivedate=4 July 2015|df=}} As of March 2016 there are twenty Local Nature Reserves in Bedfordshire: eight in Bedford, eleven in Central Bedfordshire and one in Luton. The largest is [[Harrold-Odell Country Park]] with {{convert|59.3 |ha|acre}}; it is a former quarry on the bank of the River Great Ouse which has river meadows and two lakes.{{cite web|url=http://www.hocp.co.uk/about.shtml|title=Welcome to Harrold-Odell Country Park|publisher=Friends of Harrold-Odell Country Park|accessdate=24 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925054346/http://www.hocp.co.uk/about.shtml|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}} The smallest is [[Hill Rise, Bedford|Hill Rise]] at {{convert| 0.9|ha|acre}}; it is close to Bedford town centre and surrounded on three sides by houses, but it has a variety of habitats.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=529|title=Hill Rise|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=18 February 2013|accessdate=19 November 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055915/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=529|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hillrisenaturereserve.org.uk/index.html|title=Welcome to Hill Rise Nature Reserve|publisher=Hill Rise Nature Reserve|accessdate=19 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120042042/http://www.hillrisenaturereserve.org.uk/index.html|archivedate=20 November 2015|df=}} There is public access to all the sites. {{kml}} ==Key== ===Other classifications=== * '''CAONB''' = [[Chilterns Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] * '''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] * '''SSSI''' = [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] * '''WTBCN''' = [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]] ==Sites== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" !scope="col" | Site !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"| Area{{efn|The area is taken from the Natural England map of each site. (Click on the identify icon ('''i''') in the "Feature Tools" and then click on the site.)}} !scope="col" | Location{{efn|The location is taken from the Natural England details page for the site.}} !scope="col" |Borough !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are on the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Details{{efn|Details are on the pages on each site in the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=2&Submit=Search|title= Local Nature Reserves: Search results for Bedfordshire|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 6 March 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060709/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=2&Submit=Search|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }} }} !scope="col" | Other classifications !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"|[[Bromham Lake]] |[[File:Bromham Lake 7.JPG|100px|alt=Bromham Lake]] |{{convert|10.9 |ha|acre}} |[[Bromham, Bedfordshire|Bromham]]
{{coord|52.1519|-0.5005 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bromham Lake }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 025 515 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008808%27 Map] |[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073536/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=69 Details] | |The lake was created during mineral working, and birds include the [[great crested grebe]]. Other habitats include a wildflower meadow, grassland, woodland and a limestone cliff.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=69 |title=Bromham Lake |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=17 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073536/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=69 |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Browns Wood Local Nature Reserve|Browns Wood]] |[[File:Browns Wood 3.JPG|100px|alt=Browns Wood]] |{{convert|6.0 |ha|acre}} |[[Clapham, Bedfordshire|Clapham]]
{{coord|52.1807 | -0.5032 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Browns Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 025 545 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008812%27 Map] |[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304080226/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=73 Details] | |The wood was planted by the [[Duke of Bedford]] in the middle of the eighteenth century. It is ancient semi-natural woodland of beech, larch and poplar. Ground flora include [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]] and [[nettle leaved bellflower]], and there are birds such as [[great spotted woodpecker]]s and [[song thrush]]es.Information board next to Browns Wood |- ! scope="row"|[[Cooper's Hill, Bedfordshire|Cooper's Hill]] |[[File:Fir Trees on heathland - geograph.org.uk - 629499.jpg|100px|alt=Cooper's Hill]] |{{convert|12.7 |ha|acre}} |[[Ampthill]]
{{coord| 52.0273 | -0.5016 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Coopers Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 029 376 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008848%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=110 Details] |[[SSSI]], [[WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/coopers-hill|title=Cooper's Hill|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905153244/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/coopers-hill|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=}} |In the view of [[Natural England]], this site has the best remaining area in the county of heathland on the thin acidic soils of the Lower [[Greensand Ridge]]. It also has varied invertebrates and two areas of marshy woodland.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000484.pdf|title=Cooper's Hill citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=8 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304071404/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000484.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cottage Bottom Fields]] |[[File:Dunstable, Cottage Bottom Fields Local Nature Reserve (2) - geograph.org.uk - 657349.jpg|100px|alt=Cottage Bottom Fields]] |{{convert| 14.1|ha|acre}} |[[Dunstable]]
{{coord| 51.8743 | -0.4907 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Cottage Bottom Fields}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 040 206 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009388%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=702 Details] | |The site is chalk grassland on a steep slope, and the wide variety of flowers include what may be the largest population of [[Conopodium majus|pignut]] in the country. Birds include [[wheatear]]s, [[stonechat]], [[whinchat]] and [[ring ouzel]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=&ID=702|title=Cottage Bottom Fields|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=18 February 2013|accessdate=23 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925093828/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=&ID=702|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Fenlake Meadows]] |[[File:Fenlake Meadows 8.JPG|100px|alt=Fenlake Meadows]] |{{convert| 19.2|ha|acre}} | [[Bedford]]
{{coord| 52.1272 |-0.4442 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Fenlake Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 066 488 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008896%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=158 Details] | |This site is on the bank of the [[River Great Ouse]], and it is often wet and waterlogged. The meadows are grazed by cattle, and there are wetland plants of ecological interest.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=158 |title=Fenlake Meadows |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=1 November 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072252/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=158 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Flitton Moor]] |[[File:Cows in Flitton Moor.JPG|100px|Flitton Moor]] |{{convert|6.9 |ha|acre}} |[[Flitton]]
{{coord| 52.0124 | -0.4628 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Flitton Moor }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 056 360 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008903%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=165 Details] | |The site was open moorland in the Middle Ages, but it was converted to agricultural land in the nineteenth century. The central area is pasture with a strip of woodland around the edge. Other habitats are fen and wetland. Trees include [[Cornus (genus)|osier]]s.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=165|title= Flitton Moor|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 11 March 2015|accessdate= 21 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150925094137/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=165|archivedate= 25 September 2015|df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.greensandtrust.org/flittonSites.html|title=Flitton Moor|publisher=Greensand Trust|accessdate=21 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925130753/http://www.greensandtrust.org/flittonSites.html|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Flitwick Wood]] |[[File:Flitwick Wood 5.JPG|100px|alt=Flitwick Wood]] |{{convert| 14.2|ha|acre}} |[[Flitwick]]
{{coord|52.00222 | -0.5112 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Flitwick Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 023 348 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009516%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=812 Details] | |This is semi-natural woodland, with some ancient trees and others which have recently been planted. It has a varied flora, including [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]]s, [[wood spurge]]s and [[Primula vulgaris|primroses]], and diverse birds, bats and insects.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=812|title= Flitwick Wood|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 18 February 2013|accessdate= 22 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055821/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=812|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.centralbedfordshire.gov.uk/environment/countryside/countryside-sites/countryside-sites-mid-bedfordshire.aspx|title=Countryside Sites in Mid Central Bedfordshire|publisher=Central Bedfordshire Council|accessdate=22 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926092337/http://www.centralbedfordshire.gov.uk/environment/countryside/countryside-sites/countryside-sites-mid-bedfordshire.aspx|archivedate=26 September 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Galley and Warden Hills|Galley and Warden Hills SSSI]] |[[File:Galley Hill and Warden Hill Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 1319636.jpg|100px|alt=Galley and Warden Hills]] |{{convert|44.6 |ha|acre}} |[[Luton]]
{{coord| 51.9269 | -0.4147 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Galley and Warden Hills SSSI }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 092 265 }} |[[Luton]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008913%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=175 Details] |[[SSSI]] |The site is chalk grassland with areas of dense scrub, and it has many plants which are rare nationally and locally.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000571.pdf |title=Galley and Warden Hills citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=26 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923181244/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000571.pdf |archivedate=23 September 2015 |df= }} It has a wide variety of wild flowers and more than twenty species of butterflies.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=galley&ID=175 |title=Galley and Warden Hills SSSI |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=26 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923172330/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=galley&ID=175 |archivedate=23 September 2015 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Harrold-Odell Country Park]] |[[File:Island in Harrold Odell Country Park - geograph.org.uk - 322078.jpg|100px|alt=Island in Harrold Odell Country Park]] |{{convert|59.3 |ha|acre}} |[[Harrold, Bedfordshire|Harrold]]
{{coord| 52.2038 | -0.5981 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Harrold-Odell Country Park }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 959 571 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123098%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1188 Details] | |This former quarry is bordered on its southern and eastern side by the [[River Great Ouse]]. It has two lakes, water meadows and woodland, some of which is seasonally flooded.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=harrold&ID=1188 |title=Harrold-Odell Country Park |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=24 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925115434/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=harrold&ID=1188 |archivedate=25 September 2015 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Henlow Common and Langford Meadows]] |[[File:Langford Meadows 9.JPG|100px|alt=Langford Meadows]] |{{convert|18.4 |ha|acre}} |[[Langford, Bedfordshire|Langford]]
{{coord| 52.0503 | -0.2748 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Henlow Common and Langford Meadows}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 184 405 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009389%27 Map] |[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072411/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=703 Details] | |This site on the bank of the [[River Ivel]] is mainly grassland with areas of scrub and bushes. There are also some native trees and a stream, which make it an important area for wildlife. Plants include [[Caltha palustris|marsh marigold]]s and there are birds such as [[kingfisher]]s. The river bank has [[otter]]s and [[European water vole|water vole]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=703 |title=Henlow Common and Langford Meadows |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072411/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=703 |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hill Rise, Bedford|Hill Rise]] |[[File:Hill Rise, Bedford 3.JPG|100px|alt=Hill Rise]] |{{convert| 0.9|ha|acre}} |[[Bedford]]
{{coord| 52.1478 |-0.4710 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Hill Rise }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 047 511 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009262%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=529 Details] | |The small site is surrounded on three sides by houses, but it has a variety of habitats, woodland, meadow, scrub and two ponds. Wildlife includes [[muntjac deer]], foxes, birds, dragonflies and butterflies. |- ! scope="row"|[[Kings Wood and Glebe Meadows, Houghton Conquest]] |[[File:Long Meadow and Kings Wood - geograph.org.uk - 549499.jpg|100px|alt=Long Meadow and Kings Wood]] |{{convert| 36.1|ha|acre}} |[[Houghton Conquest]]
{{coord| 52.0512 | -0.4775 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Kingswood and Glebe Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 045 403 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008983%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=246 Details] |[[SSSI]] |This site has ash and maple woodland on heavy clay, a habitat which has become rare in lowland England. It is biologically diverse, with a number of rare species. Several plants are indicative of ancient woodland, such as [[Melica uniflora|wood melick]] and [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000638.pdf |title=Kings Wood and Glebe Meadows, Houghton Conquest citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924120403/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000638.pdf |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Marston Thrift]] |[[File:Marston Thrift 1.JPG|100px|alt=Marston Thrift]] |{{convert|55.8 |ha|acre}} |[[Cranfield]]
{{coord| 52.0651 | -0.5820 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Marston Thrift }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 973 417 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009025%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=289 Details] |[[SSSI]] |Like Kings Wood and Glebe Meadows, this site has ash and maple woodland on heavy clay. It also has areas of damp grassland, and a grassland valley. It is an important site for butterflies, including the rare [[black hairstreak]].{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000684.pdf|title= Marston Thrift citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 23 August 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150924120419/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000684.pdf|archivedate= 24 September 2015|df= }}{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=marston&ID=289|title= Marston Thrift|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 18 February 2013|accessdate= 23 August 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151119060008/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=marston&ID=289|archivedate= 19 November 2015|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Maulden Church Meadow]] |[[File:Maulden Church Meadow 5.JPG|100px|alt=Maulden Church Meadow]] |{{convert|3.3 |ha|acre}} |[[Maulden]]
{{coord|52.0321 | -0.4577 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Maulden Church Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 059 382 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009028%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=292 Details] |[[SSSI]] |This is unimproved pasture on the [[Lower Greensand Group|Lower Greensand Ridge]]. It has many grass and herb species, and there are small areas of acidic grassland. An open pond has aquatic plants, while two ponds which have been filled in have a varied marsh vegetation.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000684.pdf|title=Maulden Church Meadow citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924120419/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000684.pdf|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Mowsbury Hill]] |[[File:Mowsbury Hill 5.JPG|100px|alt=Mowsbury Hill]] |{{convert|2.8 |ha|acre}} |[[Bedford]]
{{coord| 52.1668 |-0.4428 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Mowsbury Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 066 532 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009040%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=304 Details] |[[Scheduled Monument|SM]] |The site is an old orchard with a wildflower meadow, woodland, scrub, a moat and ponds.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=304|title=Mowsbury Hill|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=|accessdate=1 November 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304074827/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=304|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} It is also the site of an early [[British Iron Age|Iron Age]] [[Hillforts in Britain|hillfort]] and a medieval moated settlement with two fishponds.{{NHLE|num=1015588|desc=Mowsbury Hill: slight univallate hillfort and medieval moated site|accessdate= 1 November 2015}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Park Wood, Bedford]] |[[File:Park Wood, Bedford 5.JPG|100px|alt=Park Wood]] |{{convert|5.2 |ha|acre}} |[[Bedford]]
{{coord| 52.1563 | -0.4724 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Park Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 046 520 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271134140%27 Map] |[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304065736/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1196 Details] | |The site has diverse habitats with mature trees, grassland, scrub and ponds. Flowers include [[Ophrys apifera|bee]] and [[Anacamptis pyramidalis|pyramidal orchids]]. An orchard has been planted with traditional fruit trees.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1196 |title=Park Wood, Bedford |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=19 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304065736/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1196 |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Putnoe Wood]] |[[File:Putnoe Wood 8.jpg|100px|alt=Putnoe Wood]] |{{convert|10.4 |ha|acre}} |[[Bedford]]
{{coord|52.1623 | -0.4415 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Putnoe Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 067 527 }} |[[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009086%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=350 Details] | |This is ancient woodland with hazel coppice in the northern half, and the ground flora has areas of bluebells.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=350 |title=Putnoe Wood |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=2 November 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304080807/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=350 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} Bird species include [[Common wood pigeon|wood pigeons]], [[blue tit]]s and [[great tit]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.putnoemowsburyfriends.org.uk/pdf/Bird%20count%20PW%2012.02.2012.pdf|title=Putnoe Woods Bird Count 12-02-2012|publisher=Friends of Putnoe Wood and Mowsbury Hillfort|accessdate=2 November 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304075136/http://www.putnoemowsburyfriends.org.uk/pdf/Bird%20count%20PW%2012.02.2012.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The| Riddy|The Riddy}} |[[File:The Riddy and River ivel.JPG|100px|alt=The Riddy and River Ivel]] |{{convert|8.4 |ha|acre}} |[[Sandy, Bedfordshire|Sandy]]
{{coord| 52.1243|-0.2968 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= The Riddy }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 167 487 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009928%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1207 Details] |[[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url= http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/the-riddy |title= The Riddy |publisher= Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate= 13 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6Mj3VMLL9?url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/the-riddy |archivedate= 18 January 2014 |df= }} |This water meadow is one of the few surviving areas of flood plain of the [[River Ivel]]. Aquatic plants include [[Ranunculus sceleratus|celery leaved buttercup]] and [[Alisma|water plantain]], and there are birds such as [[lapwing]]s, [[fieldfare]]s and [[redwing]]s. [[European water vole|Water voles]] are found along the river.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1207 |title=The Riddy |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=19 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060848/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1207 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stotfold Mill Meadows]] |[[File:Stotfold Mill Meadows 3.JPG|100px|alt=Stotfold Mill Meadows]] |{{convert|3.4 |ha|acre}} |[[Stotfold]]
{{coord| 52.0143 | -0.2179 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Stotfold Mill Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 224 366 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271475829%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1675 Details] | |The meadows are on the east bank of the [[River Ivel]], and have water birds and invertebrates such as frogs, toads and newts. The site also has meadows with a number of ponds, and an area of woodland.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1675|title=Stotfold Mill Meadows|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=19 February 2013|accessdate=4 October 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055728/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=1675|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Totternhoe Knolls]] |[[File:Totternhoe Knolls 5.JPG|100px|alt=Totternhoe Knolls]] |{{convert| 13.3|ha|acre}} |[[Totternhoe]]
{{coord|51.8880 | -0.5789 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Totternhoe Knolls }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 979 220 }} |[[Central Bedfordshire|Central]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009206%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=471 Details] |[[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]],{{cite web|url=http://www.chilternsaonb.org/ccbmaps/705/137/totternhoe-knolls.html|title=Totternhoe Knolls|publisher=Chilterns Conservation Board|accessdate=13 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222161544/http://www.chilternsaonb.org/ccbmaps/705/137/totternhoe-knolls.html|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=}} [[Scheduled Monument|SM]],{{NHLE|num=1020772|desc=Totternhoe Castle: a motte and bailey castle, medieval quarries and cultivation terraces|accessdate=10 September 2015}} [[SSSI]], [[WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/totternhoe-knolls-and-quarry|title=Totternhoe|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=10 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926110945/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/totternhoe-knolls-and-quarry|archivedate=26 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} |Part of this site was formerly a chalk quarry. It is now grassland with a rich variety of plant species, including some that are now rare. There are a number of orchids and a wide variety of invertebrates, including butterflies such as the scarce [[small blue]] and [[Hamearis lucina|Duke of Burgundy]].{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001520.pdf|title= Totternhoe Knolls citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 10 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304033828/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001520.pdf|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=Totternhoe&ID=471|title=Totternhoe Knolls|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=10 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925113227/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=Totternhoe&ID=471|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}} |- |} ==See also== *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Bedfordshire]] *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in England]] {{commons category}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} {{coord|52|05|N|0|25|W|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Local Nature Reserves in Bedfordshire}} {{LNR lists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Local Nature Reserves in Bedfordshire| ]] [[Category:Lists of Local Nature Reserves|Bedford]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Cherimoya_tree_hg.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Detail of a [[fruiting]] ''[[Annona cherimola]]'', with [[cherimoya]] at center]] This '''list of cherimoya cultivars''' includes [[cultivar]]s and [[Plant variety (law)|varieties]] of [[cherimoya]], the [[fruit]] of ''[[Annona cherimola]]''.
{{Expand-list|date=December 2011}} ;Andrews ;Amarilla ;Asca ;Baste: thick-skinned. ;Bayott: (Bays x ott) Small to medium, smooth ovoid. ;Bays: Tree broad, to {{convert|6|m|ft}} fruits round, medium size, light green, skin shows fingerprint like marks. Flavor good, almost [[lemon]]y. ;Bays Mt ;Behl: very vigorous growing, self-pollinating cherimoya that is very juicy, complex flavours, excellent sweetness and acidity. It gives pierce, el bumpo, and NATA run for its money. No grit at all, smooth thin skin, has hint of vanilla, banana, raspberry, pine apple. Taste varies according to when picked. It is a seedling of unknown variety. ;Big Sister: Sibling of Sabor. Fruit large, very smooth, good flavor. Often self-fruitful. ;Blanca ;Booth: Among hardiest of cherimoya, does well in most present growing areas. Tree {{convert|6|m|ft}} to {{convert|9|m|ft}} high. Fruit is conical, medium size, rather seedy, with flavor that suggests [[papaya]]. ;Bronceada: Fruit of large size, conical shape and large number of bottles. Relatively thick skin, tan to yellow in maturity. Excellent organoleptic quality, with many seeds. ;Bronceada Mt ;Burtons Mt ;Burton's Favorite ;Campas ;Canaria: Fruit with a rounded conical shape, medium size, smooth skin, canary yellow color, attractive. Pulp white something fibrous, very juicy and firm, aromatic, acidulated and of good flavor. ;Capucha ;Carter: Long-conical, but not shouldered; smooth or faintly fingerprinted; skin green to bronze; bears well. Late. Leaves wavy or twisted. ;Chaffey: Tree rather open, fast growing. For coastal areas. Fruit small to medium, round, impressa type, with high, lemony flavor. ;Chaffey Mt ;Chavez: Fruits up to {{convert|1.5|kg|lb}} ;Chiuna 1 ;Chiuna 2 ;Chiuna 3 ;Concha Corriente ;Concha Lisa: Rounded fruit with fingerprints areoles. Soft, creamy white pulp. Good conservation in cold. Early maturation. ;Concha Pesada ;Concha Picuda ;Conde Concha ;Copucha ;Cortés II-31: Pulp with little seed, juicy and sweet. Low skin percentage and skin thickness is 1 mm and very resistant. ;Cumbe ;Cuero Dechando ;Dedo de Dama ;Deliciosa: Long-conical, prominently [[papillate]]; skin thin, slightly downy; variable in flavor; only fair in quality; generally bears well but does not ship well; cold-resistant. Midseason. ;Deliciosa Mt ;Ecuador: Tree broad, branches limber, spreading. Selected for superior hardiness. Fruit medium, quite dark green, mammillated, flavor good. ;El Bumpo: Fruit conical, medium size, mammillated, not suited for commerce. Skin soft, practically edible. Flavor among the finest. ;Favourite ;Favourite Mt ;Fino de Jete: Has skin type ''Impressa'', are smooth or slightly concave at the edges. The fruit is round, oval, heart-shaped or kidney-shaped. The seeds are enclosed in the carpels and so do not detach easily, the flavour balances intense sweetness with slight acidity. ;Funchal: Cultivar from ''Madeira Island'' ;Guayacuyán ;Honeyhart: Medium, skin smooth, plated, yellowish green. Pulp has smooth texture, excellent flavor, very juicy. ;Impresa: with "fingerprint" depressions ;Juliana ;Juniana ;Kempsey ;Kent (PK) ;Knight: Tree has medium vigor, medium-sized pale green wavy leaves. Fruit has minor protuberances, a thin skin, a slightly grainy texture and is quite sweet. ;Libby: Tree large. Fruit round conical; early harvest. Sweet, strong flavor. ;Lisa: almost smooth ;Local Serena ;Lope Concha ;Madeira: Bulky fruit usually with thick green peel. It has a heart shape, having a skin with some small protuberances. Its pulp is white, sweet, creamy, juicy, having a slightly acid and delicate, with a pronounced fragrance. The color of the skin can range from bright green, yellow-green or bronze-green. Cultivar from ''Madeira Island'' ;Mateus-II: Cultivar from ''Madeira Island'' ;Margarita ;McPherson: Tree pyramidal, vigorous, to {{convert|9|m|ft}}. Fruits small to medium in size, conical, dark green, not seedy. Flavor suggests [[banana]], sweetness varies with temperature while maturing. ;Mossman ;Ñamas ;Names ;Nata: Tree vigorous, bears quickly, flowers profuse, tendency to self-pollinating. Fruits smooth, light green, conical, {{convert|.7|kg|lb}} to {{convert|1.1|kg|lb}}. Skin thin, tender. Flavor has good sweet-acid balance. ;Negra ;Ott: Tree strong growing. Fruit medium, heart shaped tuberculate, flesh yellow, seedy, very sweet. Matures early. ;P43 Mt ;P52 Mt ;Papilonado: with fleshy, nipple-like protrusions ;Perry Vidal: Cultivar from ''Madeira Island'' ;Pierce: Tree is vigorous with large dark green leaves. Fruit is medium-sized elongated conically shaped with very smooth skin and a high sugar content. ;Piña: Fruit of conical shape with very marked protuberances, medium size, with thin skin, dark green-opaque. White and juicy pulp, excellent aroma reminiscent of a pineapple. Late maturity. ;Piña Mt ;Pinchua: Thin-skinned ;PK2 Mt ;PK 31 ;Plomiza ;Popocay ;Q Mt ;Reretai Mt ;Rio Negro: Heart shaped fruits weighing {{convert|0.8|kg|lb}} to {{convert|1|kg|lb}} ;Rugosa ;Ryerson: Long-conical, smooth or fingerprinted, with thick, tough, green or yellow green skin; of fair quality; ships well. Leaves wavy or twisted. ;Sabor: Sibling of "Big Sister". Fruit mammillated, varies in size, not usually large. Among the best in flavor. ;San Miguel ;Sander: Fruits with moderate number of seeds ;Santa Julia ;Selma: Pink flesh ;Serenense Larga ;Serenense Lisa ;Smoothey ;Spain: Small to medium, smooth, conical; [[banana]] flavor ;Terciopelo or Felpa ;Tetilado: with fleshy, nipple-like protrusions ;Tocarema ;Tuberculada: with conical protrusions having wartlike tips ;Tumba ;Umbonada: with rounded protrusions ;Whaley: Tree moderately vigorous. Fruit medium to large elongated conical, tuberculate, light green, flavor good. Seed enclosed in an obtrusive sac of flesh. ;White: Tree open, unkempt; to {{convert|11|m|ft}}, needs forming. Fruit large, to {{convert|2|kg|lb}}4 pounds, conical, with superficial small lumps (umbonate). Flesh juicy, flavor weak, suggesting [[mango]]-[[papaya]].<ref name="crfg-cherimoya">{{cite web | url = http://www.crfg.org/pubs/ff/cherimoya.html | title = CHERIMOYA | accessdate = 2008-04-20 | date = 1996 | work = CRFG Fruit Facts | publisher = California Rare Fruit Growers }}</ref><ref name="newcrops-cherimoya">{{cite web | url = http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/morton/cherimoya.html | title = Cherimoya | accessdate = 2008-04-18 | last = Morton | first = Julia F | authorlink = Purdue University | date = 1999-04-02 | pages = 65–69 | work = New Crops | publisher = Department of Horticulture & Landscape Architecture, Purdue University }}</ref><ref name="vcc">{{cite web |url=http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/counties/ceventura/Agriculture265/Cherimoya.htm |title=Cherimoya |accessdate=2008-04-20 |author=Robert Vieth, Master Gardener |authorlink=University of California, Davis |work=Minor subtropicals |publisher=[[University of California Division of Agriculture and Natural Resources|Ventura County Cooperative Extension]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070806030013/http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/counties/ceventura/Agriculture265/Cherimoya.htm |archivedate=2007-08-06 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Bridg">{{cite web | url = http://edoc.hu-berlin.de/dissertationen/bridg-hannia-2000-03-24/HTML/brigd-ch1.html | title = Micropropagation and Determination of the in vitro Stability of ''Annona cherimola'' Mill. and ''Annona muricata'' L. | accessdate = 2008-04-20 | last = Bridg | first = Hannia | date = 2001-05-03 | publisher = Zertifizierter Dokumentenserver der [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin]] }}</ref><ref name="calmoya">{{cite web | url = http://www.calimoya.com/about/about-cherimoyas.html | title = What are some delicious ways to serve a cherimoya? | accessdate = 2008-04-20 | work = All About Cherimoyas | publisher = Calimoya, Condor Ridge Ranc }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Gardiazabal |first1=Francisco |last2=Rosenberg |first2=Gregorio |date=1993 |title=El cultivo del chirimoyo |language=Spanish |location=Valparaíso, Chile |publisher=Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Facultad de Agronomía |pages=145 |isbn=978-956-17-0261-5 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Bonaventure |first1=Léon |title=A cultura da cherimóia e de seu híbrido atemóia |language=Portuguese |location=São Paulo, Brazil |publisher=Nobel |date=1999 |pages=182 |isbn=978-85-213-1094-5 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Agustín | first1 = J. A. | title = Advances in research of genetic resources of cherimoya (Annona cherimola Mill.) in Michoacán State, Mexico | journal = Acta Horticulturae | volume = | issue = 497 | pages = 189–194 | date = August 1999 | url = https://www.ishs.org/ishs-book/497 | isbn = 978-9066059610 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2009:197:0010:0013:EN:PDF | title = COUNCIL REGULATION (EC) No 510/2006 ‘CHIRIMOYA DE LA COSTA TROPICAL DE GRANADA-MÁLAGA’ | accessdate = 2018-02-28 | date = 2009-08-21 | publisher = Official Journal of the European Union }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://repositorio.ul.pt/bitstream/10451/9547/1/ulfc103119_tm_filipa_santos.pdf | title = Avaliação do potencial funcional de frutos tradicionais e a sua influência na saúde | last = Filipa | first = Santos | accessdate = 2018-02-28 | date = 2013 | work = | publisher = Universidade de Lisboa | location = Lisboa, Portugal | page= | pages= 101 | language= portuguese }}</ref> ==See also== *[[Lists of cultivars]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Breed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cherimoya cultivars}} [[Category:Annona]] [[Category:Lists of cultivars]]

revision.text:
These are the main [[river]]s of [[Belgium]].
All of Belgium is drained into the [[North Sea]], except the municipality of [[Momignies]] (Macquenoise), which is drained by the river [[Oise (river)|Oise]] into the [[English Channel]]. Rivers that flow into the sea are sorted alphabetically. Rivers that flow into other rivers are sorted by the proximity of their points of confluence to the sea. Some rivers (e.g. Moselle, Rhine, Seine) do not flow through Belgium themselves, but they are mentioned for having Belgian tributaries. They are given in ''italics''. Below, the Belgian rivers are given alphabetically. See also [[:Category:Rivers of Belgium]]. If the names are different in French, Dutch or German, they are given in parentheses (only given if the river comes into French, Dutch or German-speaking territory).
Note for additions: Please remember to add the city where the river meets for each river. For an alphabetical overview of rivers of Belgium, see the category [[:Category:Rivers of Belgium]].
{{TOC right}}
==By basin==

revision.text:
These are the main [[river]]s of the Netherlands.
All of the Netherlands is drained into the [[North Sea]], partly via the [[IJsselmeer]] lake. In the list below, rivers that flow into the sea are sorted following the North Sea coast (including IJsselmeer) from the Belgian border near [[Knokke]] to the German border near [[Emden]]. Rivers that flow into other rivers are sorted by the proximity of their points of confluence to the sea.
A large part of the Netherlands is located in the [[Rhine–Meuse–Scheldt delta]]. The network of rivers is rather complex. The main routes of the rivers Scheldt, Meuse and Rhine are indicated in '''bold'''.
At the end of this article the rivers of the Netherlands are given alphabetically. See also [[:Category:Rivers of the Netherlands]] and [[:Category:Rhine-Meuse-Scheldt delta]].
Note for additions: please remember to add the city where the river meets for each river.

the IJsselmeer near [[Genemuiden]]) **[[Vecht (Overijssel)]] (near [[Zwolle]]) ***[[Regge (river)|Regge]] (near [[Ommen]]) ***[[Dinkel]] (in [[Neuenhaus]], Germany) *[[Lauwers]] (in [[De Marne|Lauwersoog]]) *[[Ems (river)|Ems]] (near [[Delfzijl]])

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
'''Malpai Borderlands''' is a region, or areal feature, along the [[U.S.-Mexico border]] at the [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]] state line. It encompasses the extreme southeast corner of Arizona and the southwest corner of New Mexico describe the general vicinity. It includes areas inside the [[U.S. state]]s of Arizona and New Mexico as well as the [[Mexican state]]s of [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] and [[Sonora]].
The lowest elevations in this area are about 3,700 feet in the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge area. Highest elevation is roughly 8,500 feet above mean sea level (AMSL). Mountain ranges generally run north-south. Terrain is described as including desert shrub, Tobosa grassland, [[Ponderosa Pine]] forest, and [[Douglas Fir]]. Some cattle ranching takes place in the region. The [[geomorphic province]]s include Madrean and [[Chihuahuan Desert|Chihuahuan desert]]s.
The name "Malpai", relates to a type of "[[desert pavement]]", formed by wind ([[Eolian processes|eolian]]) processes, and is called [[Malapai (geology)|Malapai]].
==Variant names== The Borderlands are sometimes referred to by the name of a larger region encompassing Malpai Borderlands: '''Southwest Borderlands'''. The name is sometimes misspelled ''Maipai'' Borderlands. Some references describe it as being inside the Chihuahuan Desert.
==Unofficial extents of the region== Papers on the region describe geographic features that partly define it.
The '''United States portion''' of this region probably includes portions of [[Grant County, New Mexico]], [[Hidalgo County, New Mexico]], and [[Cochise County, Arizona]]. Major geographic features of the area include portions of the San Simon, San Bernardino, Animas, and Playas valleys as well as rivers of the same name. Except for [[Arizona]]'s [[San Simon Valley]] and San Simon River, the areas mentioned appear to be entirely south of present-day [[Interstate 10]]. Government reservations in this region include all of [[Coronado National Forest]] (US Forest Service) east of US191 and San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, (US Fish and Wildlife Service).
In the [[Mexico|Mexican]] state of [[Sonora, Mexico|Sonora]], [[Dieciocho de Agosto]], [[Sierra de los Ajos]] (sometimes written Sierra Ajos), [[Agua Prieta]], ''frontera'' (frontier), [[Cañón del Oso]] and [[Nogales, Sonora|Nogales]] are mentioned. In the state of [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], the area of [[Janos, Chihuahua|Janos]] is mentioned.
===Variant descriptions=== A fire history report on the region suggests some definitions may include areas as far west as the Huachuca Mountains of Arizona.
==Area under scientific study== A wide array of individuals and organizations are eyeing competing demands on these lands. The [[United States Forest Service|US Forest Service]], Arizona Geological Survey, [[United States Geological Survey|US Geological Survey]], Natural Resource Conservation Service (formerly Soil Conservation Service), [[University of New Mexico]], The Nature Conservancy, [[New Mexico Department of Fish and Game]], [[University of Arizona]], and [[Coronado National Forest]] have been active in studying the future of the area.
==See also== * [[Madrean sky islands]] (article with map of area) * [[Janos Biosphere Reserve]]
==Sources== * "Toward Integrated Research, Land Management, and Ecosystem Protection in the Malpai Borderlands: Conference Summary," [[Rocky Mountain Research Station]] Report P-10, [[United States Forest Service|US Forest Service]], July 1999. * Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) Database, US Geological Survey.
==External links== *[http://www.malpaiborderlandsgroup.org/ Malpai Borderlands Group, (a nonprofit)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060503185951/http://taipan.nmsu.edu/malpai/gray.html Map of region] *[http://geochange.er.usgs.gov/sw/responses/malpai/ US Geological Survey web page on region]
{{coord missing|Arizona}}
[[Category:Madrean Region]] [[Category:Malpaíses (landform)]] [[Category:Deserts and xeric shrublands]] [[Category:Temperate coniferous forests]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Mexico]] [[Category:Ecoregions of the United States]] [[Category:Deserts and xeric shrublands in the United States]] [[Category:Temperate coniferous forests of the United States]] [[Category:Regions of the Western United States]] [[Category:Regions of Arizona]] [[Category:Regions of New Mexico]] [[Category:Chihuahuan Desert]] [[Category:Geography of Chihuahua (state)]] [[Category:Geography of Sonora]] [[Category:Geography of Cochise County, Arizona]] [[Category:Geography of Grant County, New Mexico]] [[Category:Geography of Hidalgo County, New Mexico]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Mare Crisium Studios}} {{Infobox Lunar mare |name = Mare Crisium |image = [[Image:Mare Crisium (LRO).png|240px]] |caption = [[Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter|LRO]] image |eponym = Sea of Crises |coordinates = {{coord|17.0|N|59.1|E|globe:moon_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |diameter = {{convert|555|km|mi|abbr=on}}<ref name=USGS/> }} '''Mare Crisium''' (the "'''Sea of Crises'''") is a [[lunar mare]] located in the [[Moon]]'s Crisium basin, just northeast of [[Mare Tranquillitatis]]. The basin is of the [[Lunar geologic timescale|Pre-Imbrian]] period, 4.55 to 3.85 billion years ago.
==Characteristics==
Mare Crisium is {{convert|555|km|mi|abbr=on}} in diameter,<ref name=USGS>{{cite web |title=Moon Mare/Maria |publisher=USGS Astrogeology |work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature |url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/SearchResults?target=MOON&featureType=Mare%2C%20maria |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> and {{convert|176000|km2}} in area. It has a very flat floor, with a ring of [[wrinkle ridge]]s (''dorsa'') toward its outer boundaries. These are [[Dorsa Tetyaev]], [[Dorsum Oppel]], [[Dorsum Termier]], and [[Dorsa Harker]]. The cape-like feature protruding into the southeast of the mare is [[Promontorium Agarum]]. On the western rim of the mare is the [[Palimpsest#Usage in other disciplines|palimpsest]] [[Yerkes (crater)|Yerkes]], and [[Lick (crater)|Lick]] to the southeast is similar. The [[Impact crater|crater]] [[Picard (crater)|Picard]] is located just to the east of Yerkes, and northwest of Picard are the craters [[Peirce (crater)|Peirce]] and [[Swift (lunar crater)|Swift]]. The [[ray system]] of the crater [[Proclus (crater)|Proclus]] overlie the northwestern mare. [[Mare Anguis]] can be seen northeast of Mare Crisium.<ref>{{cite web | title=Mare Crisium | work=lunar.arc.nasa.gov | url=http://lunar.arc.nasa.gov/science/atlas/mare/mcrisium.htm | accessdate=October 18, 2007 }}</ref>
A [[mass concentration (astronomy)|mass concentration]] (mascon), or gravitational high, was identified in the center of Mare Crisium from Doppler tracking of the five [[Lunar Orbiter program|Lunar Orbiter]] spacecraft in 1968.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.161.3842.680 | title = Mascons: Lunar Mass Concentrations | year = 1968 | author = P. M. Muller, W. L. Sjogren | journal = Science | volume = 161 | issue = 3842 | pages = 680–684 | pmid=17801458}}</ref> The mascon was confirmed and mapped at higher resolution with later orbiters such as [[Lunar Prospector]] and [[Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory|GRAIL]]. <gallery heights="240px" mode="packed"> File:Crisium basin topo.jpg|Topographic map File:Crisium basin GRAIL gravity.jpg|Gravity map based on [[Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory|GRAIL]] </gallery>
==Names== Like most of the other maria on the Moon, Mare Crisium was named by [[Giovanni Riccioli]], whose 1651 nomenclature system has become standardized.<ref>Ewen A. Whitaker, ''Mapping and Naming the Moon'' (Cambridge University Press, 1999), p.61.</ref>
By the 17th century, Mare Crisium had acquired the name 'Caspian Sea', being labelled as such by [[Thomas Harriot]], [[Pierre Gassendi]] and [[Michael Van Langren]]. Ewen A. Whitaker speculates that it received this name because it occupies roughly the same position on the Moon's face as does the [[Caspian Sea]] on Earth, with respect to [[T and O map|maps of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East]].<ref name= "witaker_p7">Ewen A. Whitaker, ''Mapping and Naming the Moon'' (Cambridge University Press, 1999), p.7.</ref> The English astronomer [[William Gilbert (astronomer)|William Gilbert]]'s map of ''c''.1600 calls it 'Brittania' after [[Great Britain|Britain]].<ref name= "witaker_p7" />
==Observation and exploration== Mare Crisium is just visible from Earth with the naked eye as a small dark spot on the edge of the Moon's face.
It is the site of the crash-landing of Soviet [[Luna 15]] probe in 1969. A soil sample from Mare Crisium was successfully brought to Earth on 22 August 1976 by the Soviet lunar mission [[Luna 24]].
==Views== <gallery heights="180px" mode="packed"> File:Mare Crisium 4191 h3.jpg|[[Lunar Orbiter 4]] image File:Mare Crisium AS17-M-0913-0919-0924.jpg|These are three views of northern Mare Crisium on the moon, taken by the mapping camera of the [[Apollo 17]] mission in 1972, facing north-northeast from an average altitude of 118 km on Revolution 27 of the mission. At the right is the east margin of Mare Crisium, with the north tip of [[Promontorium Agarum]] visible in the foreground, and [[Mare Anguis]] near the central horizon. The crater [[Eimmart (crater)|Eimmart]] is visible in both the right and central photos as a bright patch (near the top in each). The center photo shows an obvious lack of large craters in the mare indicating a relatively young age of the basalt, and the crater Eimmart C is visible as a ring at the edge of the mare near the top center. The left photo shows the western margin of the mare, with the crater [[Peirce (crater)|Peirce]] (larger) and [[Swift (lunar crater)|Swift]] (smaller) in the mare, and the large crater [[Cleomedes (crater)|Cleomedes]] near the central horizon. The rays of the crater [[Proclus (crater)|Proclus]] (further to the west, not shown) are prominent in the mare. These photos were taken within minutes of each other. The sun elevation drops from 60 degrees at right to 46 degrees at left as the [[Apollo Command/Service Module|Command Module]] ''America'' orbited the moon. Image:Mare Crisium AS11-43-6484.jpg|Low-altitude view of southern Mare Crisium from [[Apollo 11]], facing northwest and showing [[Shapley (crater)|Shapley]] crater near center at the edge of the mare, and the distal wall of [[Greaves (crater)|Greaves]] crater near the horizon. </gallery>
==In popular culture== *In [[Robert A. Heinlein]]'s novel ''[[The Moon is a Harsh Mistress]]'', Mare Crisium is the site of a lunar colony named Luna City. *"[[The Sentinel (short story)|The Sentinel]]", the [[short story]] from which [[Arthur C. Clarke]] developed the film ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' with [[Stanley Kubrick]], takes place on the Mare Crisium. * In the game "Mass Effect" (2007), the assignment UNC: Rogue VI, operational zone is established in the southern portion of Mare Crisium. * Andrew Lagowski, under his SETI alias, included a track called Mare Crisium on his 1996 album The Geometry of the Night.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-geometry-of-night-mw0000186116|title=The Geometry of Night - S.E.T.I. {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|website=AllMusic|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> * In "[[Call of Duty: Black Ops]]" (2010), the Zombie map Moon takes place in Mare Crisium. *The Brazilian [[death metal]] band [[Krisiun]] is named after the crater.
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{commons category|Mare Crisium}} * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/seandoran/42282124771/ High resolution lunar overflight video] by Seán Doran, based on LRO data, that passes near Mare Crisium (see [https://www.flickr.com/photos/136797589@N04/albums/72157686992929766/with/35498090194/ album] for more); a longer version that starts over the western margin of [[Mare Fecunditatis]] is on [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CGoD3G5JDc0 YouTube]
{{Lunar maria}}
[[Category:Maria on the Moon|Crisium]]
