revision.text:
The '''Standard Uptake Fraction''' (SUF) is the relative distribution of water uptake of a plant in a soil with a uniform water potential.<ref>{{Cite journal | url=https://www.hydrol-earth-syst-sci.net/16/2957/2012/hess-16-2957-2012.html | doi=10.5194/hess-16-2957-2012| title=A simple three-dimensional macroscopic root water uptake model based on the hydraulic architecture approach| journal=Hydrology and Earth System Sciences| volume=16| issue=8| pages=2957–2971| year=2012| last1=Couvreur| first1=V.| last2=Vanderborght| first2=J.| last3=Javaux| first3=M.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1007/s00285-017-1111-z| pmid=28255663| pmc=5591877|title = Towards quantitative root hydraulic phenotyping: Novel mathematical functions to calculate plant-scale hydraulic parameters from root system functional and structural traits| journal=Journal of Mathematical Biology| volume=75| issue=5| pages=1133–1170|year = 2017|last1 = Meunier|first1 = F.| last2=Couvreur| first2=V.| last3=Draye| first3=X.| last4=Vanderborght| first4=J.| last5=Javaux| first5=M.}}</ref> The SUF gives the ratio coefficient to obtain the equivalent soil water potential sensed by the plant. It is one of the macroscopic parameter for the hydraulic properties of the root system.
<math>SUF = \dfrac{J_r}{T_{act}}</math>
<math>J_r</math> = the radial flow entering each root segment (<math>L^{3}T^{-1}</math>), and <math>T_{act}</math> = the actual transpiration (<math>L^{3}T^{-1}</math>).
In order to get this parameter, the easiest way is to deal with Functionnal-Stuctural Plant Models. They will compute the radial water flow for each root segment and then devide the total by the actual transpiration. [https://plantmodelling.shinyapps.io/marshal/ MARSHAL] is a online tools developed <ref>{{Cite journal | url=https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/05/19/139980 | doi=10.1101/139980| title=CRoot ''Box'': A Structural-Functional Modelling Framework for Root Systems| journal=bioRxiv| pages=139980| year=2017| last1=Schnepf| first1=Andrea| last2=Leitner| first2=Daniel| last3=Landl| first3=Magdalena| last4=Lobet| first4=Guillaume| last5=Mai| first5=Trung Hieu| last6=Morandage| first6=Shehan| last7=Sheng| first7=Cheng| last8=Zoerner| first8=Mirjam| last9=Vanderborght| first9=Jan| last10=Vereecken| first10=Harry}}</ref> to visualise the root system and allows to look after the '''SUF'''.
==Standard Uptake Density==
The standard uptake density (SUD) (<math>L^{-1}</math>) is the distribution of the water uptake flow rate in the soil where the water potential is uniform.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url=https://search.proquest.com/openview/1b34a7f53e951a37940477d1492389c2/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=105724|title=A simple three-dimensional macroscopic root water uptake model based on the hydraulic architecture approach|journal=Hydrology and Earth System Sciences|volume=16|issue=8|pages=2957–2971|doi=10.5194/hess-16-2957-2012|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|year=2012|last1=Couvreur|first1=V.|last2=Vanderborght|first2=J.|last3=Javaux|first3=M.}}</ref> In other words:
<math>SUD = \dfrac{SUF}{L_{segment}}</math>
<math>L_{segment}</math> = the segment length (<math>L</math>).
==Standard Sink Fraction==
The standard sink fraction (SSF) is very similar to the SUF, but instead of being a function of the root segment, it is related to the soil [[voxel]]. It is the normilised distribution of the sink term in a uniform water potential soil.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== *[[Absorption of water]] *[[Root system equivalent conductance]] *[[Compensatory conductance]]
==Notes== {{Empty section|date=September 2018}}
==References==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Soil]] [[Category:Water]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Mackinacsugarloaf.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Sugar Loaf, as seen from Point Lookout]] '''Sugar Loaf''' is a 75-foot-high (23m) landlocked rock or stack in the interior of [[Mackinac Island]] in Lake Huron. Created by erosion during the period of postglacial [[Lake Algonquin]], Sugar Loaf is the largest post-glacial erosion feature in the [[Straits of Mackinac]].
The immense rock, which consists of resistant limestone [[breccia]], was cut off from Ancient Mackinac Island or the ''Turtle's Back'' by the glacial meltwaters of Lake Algonquin. Polar storms released by the retreating ice sheet created erosional forces much stronger than any existing today on the [[Great Lakes]].
The rock lies within the boundaries of the [[Mackinac Island State Park]] near the junction of Crooked Tree Road and Sugar Loaf Road. It can be seen from ''Point Lookout'', near the Island's highest point.
==Its name== The primary sweetening enjoyed by people of all backgrounds on the frontier Great Lakes was [[maple sugar]], packed into [[Wiigwaasi-makak|cone-shaped baskets]] or ''makakoon'' of [[birchbark]]. Sugar Loaf Rock was named for its resemblance to one of these cones.
==Its lore== A wide variety of stories were told by [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] and frontier dwellers about Sugar Loaf. It was said by some to be the home of [[Gitchie Manitou]]. Other tales suggested that the rock was the final form taken by a man afflicted with [[hubris]] who broke a [[taboo]] and was punished by being petrified into the form of a giant stone. The profile in limestone, affixed to the side of Sugar Loaf Rock, of a male face may have suggested this legend. The profile is said to be that of the lost soul, who can never escape the identity he took upon his moral condemnation.
Sugar Loaf Rock appears to have been used as a site of ritual burials and inhumations. In 1831, [[Alexis de Tocqueville]] and his friend [[Gustave de Beaumont]] visited Mackinac Island. De Beaumont reported that the rock was filled with "crevices and faults where the Indians sometimes deposed the bones of the dead." Any such deposits have long since disappeared.
A natural cave passes through Sugar Loaf from side to side, too small for passage by any but adventurous children.
==Sources== *George W. Pierson, "Tocqueville and Beaumont in America" (New York City: Oxford University Press, 1938), page 302.
{{Coord|45.86164|-84.61744|type:landmark_region:US-MI|display=title}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=May 2011}} {{infobox television | | show_name = The Secret Adventures of Jules Verne | image = | caption = | runtime = 60 min. | creator = [[Gavin Scott (Screenwriter)|Gavin Scott]] | starring = [[Michael Praed]]
[[Francesca Hunt]]
[[Michel Courtemanche]]
[[Chris Demetral]] | country = United Kingdom
Canada | executive_producer = Nicolas Clermont
Pierre de Lespinois
Neil Dunn
[[Michael Huffington]]
Richard Jackson
[[Gavin Scott (Screenwriter)|Gavin Scott]] | network = [[CBC Television|CBC]] and syndicated | opentheme = ''The Secret Adventures of Jules Verne Theme'' by [[Nick Glennie-Smith]] | camera = | first_aired = June 18, 2000 | last_aired = December 16, 2000 | num_episodes = 22 | num_seasons = 1 | website = }} '''''The Secret Adventures of Jules Verne''''' is a 22-episode [[science fiction]] television series in the [[steampunk]] genre that first aired in June 2000 on [[CBC Television]] in Canada. The series first ran in the United States on cable on The Sci-Fi Channel (now Syfy). The plot concept is predicated on a vast fictional [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy]] beginning with the revelation that [[Jules Verne]] did not merely ''write'' the stories behind his famous science fiction classic books ''[[Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea]]'', ''[[Journey to the Center of the Earth]]'' or ''[[Around the World in Eighty Days (Verne novel)|Around the World in Eighty Days]]'' — but actually experienced these adventures personally. A television technological historic footnote, this work was the first hour-long series filmed entirely in [[High-definition television|HDTV]] format. ==Characters== *Phileas Fogg as played by [[Michael Praed]] *Rebecca Fogg as played by [[Francesca Hunt]] *Passepartout as played by [[Michel Courtemanche]] *Jules Verne as played by [[Chris Demetral]] ==Premise== Jules Verne is a struggling author who joins Phileas, Rebecca, and Passepartout after a chance encounter. Phileas leads the group. Dapper, daring, intelligent, brash, and arrogant, Praed described him as essentially a more flawed version of James Bond. Rebecca Fogg is his second cousin; it is clear that Phileas and Rebecca are attracted to one another, but it remains platonic. Passepartout is Phileas' valet, and an accomplished inventor/mechanician. Although Phileas treats Passepartout very poorly (at least by today's standards), the servant is a valued member of the crew. The group's only recurring enemy is the League of Darkness, an international terrorist organization aiming to use steampunk technology to rule the world. Its leader: Count Gregory ([[Rick Overton]]), a steampunk [[cyborg]] who originally died 500 years ago. Most episodes took advantage of both the [[Wold Newton family]] and [[metafictional]] possibilities of the premise. [[Mark Twain]], the [[Holy Grail]], and [[Cardinal Richelieu]] (played by [[Michael Praed]]) all made appearances. Some parts of the show are truthfully historical, such as the mention of [[Nicolas Poussin]] or Verne's friendship with [[Alexandre Dumas]]. However, the show cannot be historically placed. For example, at least one episode ("Southern Comfort") takes place during the American Civil War (1861–1865). During the Civil War, the historical Jules Verne was already married; the fictional character remains single throughout the first season. Also, the historical Verne would have been in his mid-thirties at the time of that conflict, whereas [[Chris Demetral]], the actor who portrayed him on television, was in his mid-twenties. ==The Aurora== The Aurora is at the heart of The Secret Adventure of Jules Verne. The world's first dirigible [[airship]], property of Mr. Phileas Fogg of [[London]], it combines unexampled luxury, total mobility and an extraordinary array of weapons and gadgets. It is to this series what the [[Starship Enterprise]] is to [[Star Trek]]: both as a home base and also as the route to the world of adventure. The Aurora became Phileas' property after he won it in a poker game that was rigged by the British government. ==Episodes== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" !style="background:#cccccc;"| '''Episode''' !style="background:#cccccc;"| '''Title''' !style="background:#cccccc;"| '''Notable guest stars''' |- | 1. || ''In the Beginning'' || [[David Warner (actor)|David Warner]] and [[Rick Overton]] |- | 2. || ''Queen Victoria and the Giant Mole'' || [[Tracy Scoggins]] |- | 3. || ''Rockets of the Dead'' || [[Patrick Duffy]] |- | 4. || ''The Cardinal's Design'' || [[John Rhys-Davies]] and [[René Auberjonois]] |- | 5. || ''The Cardinal's Revenge'' || John Rhys-Davies and René Auberjonois |- | 6. || ''The Eyes of Lazarus'' || [[Michael Moriarty]] and [[Margot Kidder]] |- | 7. || ''Lord of Air and Darkness'' || [[Sonia Vigneault]] and Rick Overton |- | 8. || ''Southern Comfort'' || [[Larissa Laskin]], Sonia Vigneault and Rick Overton |- | 9. || ''Let There Be Light'' || [[Michael Yarmush]] |- | 10. || ''The Ballad of Steeley Joe'' || |- | 11. || ''The Black Glove of Melchizedek'' || [[Kim Chan]] and [[Nigel Bennett]] |- | 12. || ''Dust to Dust'' || [[Pascale Bussieres]] |- | 13. || ''The Golem '' || [[Caroline Dhavernas]] |- | 14. || ''Crusader in the Crypt'' || |- | 15. || ''The Strange Death of Professor Marechal'' || [[Polly Draper]] |- | 16. || ''The Rocket's Red Glare'' || Rick Overton |- | 17. || ''Rocket to the Moon'' || [[R. H. Thomson]] |- | 18. || ''The Inquisitor'' ||[[Mako (actor)|Mako]] |- | 19. || ''Royalty'' || Geordie Johnson |- | 20. || ''Secret of the Realm'' || Rick Overton |- | 21. || ''The Victorian Candidate'' || [[Bill Paterson (actor)|Bill Paterson]] and Keir Cutler |- | 22. || ''The Book of Knowledge'' || [[David Warner (actor)|David Warner]] and [[Michael McManus (Canadian actor)|Michael McManus]] |} ==Soundtrack== The series' main theme and incidental music was composed by [[Nick Glennie-Smith]]. In April 2011, [[Perseverance Records]] released a 2-CD soundtrack of the series' music. The soundtrack included the main theme, closing theme, "bumpers" (played at commercial breaks), and suites from every episode of the series apart from "The Book of Knowledge", for which the composer and the recording studio were unable to locate the original tapes.{{cite web|title=Interview with album editor Gergely Hubai at hans-zimmer.com|url=http://www.hans-zimmer.com/fr/newsite.php?rub=detail&id=1018|accessdate=29 March 2011}} {| class="wikitable" ! CD 1 |- ! No. !! Title !! CD 2 |- ! No. !! Title !! Length |- | 1 || Bumper #4 || 0:09 |- | 2 || The Black Glove of Melchizedek || 9:02 |- | 3 || Dust to Dust || 6:17 |- | 4 || The Golem || 3:51 |- | 5 || Crusader in the Crypt || 1:53 |- | 6 || The Strange Death of Professor Marechal || 4:32 |- | 7 || The Rocket's Red Glare || 5:53 |- | 8 || Rocket to the Moon || 3:55 |- | 9 || Bumper #5 || 0:09 |- | 10 || The Inquisitor || 5:25 |- | 11 || Royalty || 12:38 |- | 12 || Secret of the Realm || 6:00 |- | 13 || The Victorian Candidate || 7:27 |- | 14 || End Credits || 0:42 |} ==References== ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0178161|title=The Secret Adventures of Jules Verne}} * {{tv.com show|the-secret-adventures-of-jules-verne|The Secret Adventures of Jules Verne}} {{Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea}} {{Syfy Shows}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Secret Adventures of Jules Verne}} [[Category:Science fiction Westerns]] [[Category:2000s Canadian science fiction television series]] [[Category:British science fiction television programmes]] [[Category:Steampunk television series]] [[Category:Adaptations of works by Jules Verne]] [[Category:CBC Television shows]] [[Category:2000 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:2000 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:2000 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2000 British television programme endings]] [[Category:Around the World in Eighty Days]] [[Category:Journey to the Center of the Earth]] [[Category:Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea]] [[Category:British horror fiction television series]]

{{ infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]] --> | name = Thomas Alfred Coward | image = Thomas_Coward_1867-1933.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1867|1|8|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bowdon, Greater Manchester|Bowdon]] [[Cheshire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1933|1|29|1867|1|8|df=y}} | death_place = Lower Bowdon, Cheshire | occupation = {{Plainlist| * Company manager * Museum keeper }} | education = | alma_mater = Owens College (now [[Manchester University]]) | period = Late C19- | genre = | subject = {{Plainlist| * Natural history * Ornithology }} | movement = | notableworks = ''The Birds of the British Isles and Their Eggs'' }}
[[Image:"The Migration of Birds", by T.A. Coward (front cover, 1912).png|thumb|right|upright|Cover of ''The Migration of Birds''. Aside from the coat-of-arms and lettering, the design is that used by the earliest known Cambridge printer, [[John Siberch]], in 1521.]]
'''Thomas Alfred Coward''', MSc, [[Zoological Society of London|FZS]], [[Royal Entomological Society of London|FRES]], [[British Ornithologists' Union|MBOU]] (8 January 1867 – 29 January 1933), was an [[England|English]] [[ornithology|ornithologist]] and an amateur [[astronomy|astronomer]]. He wrote extensively on [[natural history]], [[local history]] and [[Cheshire]].
==Life== He was born at 8 Higher Downs, [[Bowdon, Greater Manchester|Bowdon]], [[Cheshire]] (now [[Greater Manchester]]) on 8 January 1867, the fourth and last child of Thomas and Sarah Coward. His father was a [[Congregational church|Congregational]] minister and in business as a partner in the firm of Melland and Coward, textile bleachers.<ref name=ODNB>{{Cite web |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/45766 |title= Coward, Thomas Alfred (1867–1933) |accessdate= 11 June 2011 |last=Cardwell |first=Donald |year= |work= [[Dictionary of National Biography#Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] |publisher= [[Oxford University Press]] |doi= 10.1093/ref:odnb/36241 |subscription=yes }}</ref> Coward's siblings were Charles, Alice and Annie.
After an education at Brooklands School, [[Sale, Greater Manchester|Sale]] and at [[Owens College]] (now [[Manchester University]]), Coward worked in the family business for 19 years, before it was taken over by the Bleachers' Association. His share of the proceeds from the sale of Melland and Coward was sufficient to allow him to retire from business and concentrate on his love of wildlife and the study of birds, which had developed as a child.<ref name=ODNB/><ref name=Obit>{{cite news |url=http://infotrac.galegroup.com/itw/infomark/205/888/158380354w16/purl=rc1_TTDA_0_CS252389439&dyn=5!xrn_23_0_CS252389439&hst_1?sw_aep=kccl |newspaper=[[The Times]] |title=Mr T. A. Coward |date=31 January 1933 |page=15 |issue=46356 |accessdate=11 June 2011 |subscription=yes }}</ref> He began writing articles on natural history for newspapers including ''[[The Liverpool Daily Post]]'', ''The Chester Cournant'' and ''[[The Guardian|The Manchester Guardian]]'' for which he wrote the "[[Country Diary]]" column until his death. General interest magazines for which he wrote included ''[[The Field (magazine)|The Field]]'' and ''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'' and in specialist journals such as ''[[The Zoologist]]'', ''[[Proceedings of the Zoological Society of London]]'' and ''[[British Birds (magazine)|British Birds]]''.<ref name=ODNB/>
His first book was ''The Birds of Cheshire'', published in 1900, when he was living in Hale. His three-volume ''The Birds of the British Isles and their eggs'' (1920–25) was illustrated by [[Archibald Thorburn]] and was "acknowledged as being the book that did more to popularise the study of birds than any other publication produced during the first part of the twentieth century".<ref name="Usher">{{cite web |last1=Usher |first1=Tony |title=T.A.Coward |url=http://www.10x50.com/coward/coward.htm |publisher=[[Knutsford Ornithological Society]] |accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref> It was revised by [[Arnold Boyd]] for a new edition in 1950.
He co-wrote articles and books on ornithology with [[Charles Oldham (naturalist)|Charles Oldham]], a former schoolmate.<ref name="Ibis84-3">{{cite journal|author=W. E. G.<!-- possibly William E. Glegg -->|title=Obituary: Charles Oldham |journal=[[Ibis (journal)|Ibis]] |volume=84 |issue=3 |date=July 1942 |pages=440–443 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1474-919X.1942.tb05717.x/pdf|doi=10.1111/j.1474-919X.1942.tb05717.x}}</ref>
He married his cousin Mary Milne in 1904. There is a [[Blue Plaque]] at his former home, Brentwood Villa, 6 Grange Road, Bowdon,<ref name="OP">{{cite web|url=http://openplaques.org/plaques/8447|title=Blue plaque № 8447 in Bowdon|work=Open Plaques|accessdate=30 December 2011}}</ref> to which he moved in 1911.
On his death, the {{convert|14|acre|m2|adj=on}} [[Cotterill Clough Nature Reserve]] was bought, by public subscription, in his honour.<ref name="NWN-1934-03">{{cite journal|last=Hodkinson|first=Mr J. F.|date=March 1934|title=The T. A. Coward Memorial Nature Reserves|journal=North Western Naturalist|volume=IX|issue=1|pages=3}}</ref>
His field notes are archived in the Department of Zoology at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]].
=== Jizz ===
Coward is credited with the first use in print of the term "''[[Jizz (birding)|Jizz]]''", in his "Country Diary" column of 6 December 1921 - the piece was subsequently included in his 1922 book "Bird Haunts and Nature Memories".<ref name="BB111">{{cite journal |last1=Greenwood |first1=Jeremy J.D. |authorlink1=Jeremy Greenwood |last2=Greenwood |first2= Julian G. |title=The Origin of the Birdwatching Term "Jizz" |journal=[[British Birds (magazine)|British Birds]] |date=May 2018 |volume=111 |issue=5 |page=292-294}}</ref> He attributed it to "a west-coast Irishman".<ref name="BB111" />
==Positions==
* Acting Keeper of the Manchester Museum (During [[World War I]]) * Chairman and President of the Altrincham and District Natural History and Literary Society * President of the Manchester Literary and Philosophical Society
==Bibliography==
[[File:The Birds of the British Isles and their Eggs - advert.png|thumb|Press advertisement for ''The Birds of the British Isles and their Eggs'', published in The Times, London, 6 February 1920]]
[[File:Brambling by Archibald Thorburn.png|thumb|Brambling by [[Archibald Thorburn]], one of the illustrations from ''The Birds of the British Isles and their Eggs'']]
Coward wrote a number of books on local history, natural history and birds:<ref name=WWW>{{cite web |url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U207970 | title=Coward, Thomas Alfred |work=[[Who Was Who]] |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]/[[A & C Black]] |date=December 2007 |accessdate=11 June 2011 |subscription=yes }}</ref> *''The Birds of Cheshire'', 1900, written jointly with [[Charles Oldham (naturalist)|Charles Oldham]]. *''Picturesque Cheshire'' *''The Vertebrate Fauna of Cheshire and Liverpool Bay'', 1910, written jointly with Charles Oldham and James Johnstone. * {{cite book|title=Cheshire|series=[[Cambridge County Geographies]]}} *''The Migration of Birds'', [[Cambridge University Press]], 1912 *''The Birds of the British Isles and their Eggs'', [[Frederick Warne & Co]], 1919 in two volumes, expanded to three in 1926 *''Bird Haunts and Nature Memories'', Frederick Warne & Co, 1922 *''Birds and their Young'' *''Life of the Wayside and Woodland'' *''Birds at Home and Abroad'' *''Life of Birds'' *''Bird and Other Nature Problems'', Frederick Warne & Co, 1931 *''Cheshire – Traditions and History'' *''The Mammalian Fauna of Cheshire''
===Contributions=== *''The Practical Handbook of British Birds'', Witherby & Co, 1920 *{{Cite book | publisher = J. Cape, | pages = 256 p, [12] leaves of plates : ill (music) ; 20 cm. | last = White | first = Walter Walmesley | title = Bird life in Devon | location = London | year = 1931 }} (Foreword)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Thomas Coward}} {{wikisource author|Thomas Alfred Coward}} * {{ODNBweb|id=45766}} * {{Journalisted}} * {{Gutenberg author | id=Coward,+T.+A.}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Thomas Alfred Coward}} * [https://books.google.com/books?id=qL09AAAAYAAJ ''The Birds of the British Isles and Their Eggs''] Google Books. Retrieved 11 June 2011. * [https://www.theguardian.com/profile/thomas-coward Guardian 'Country Diary' columns]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Trevor Findlay''' is director of the Nuclear Energy Futures Project at the [[Centre for International Governance Innovation]] (CIGI) in [[Waterloo, Ontario]]. He heads the CIGI project on the future of the [[IAEA]]. Findlay wrote the report on the ''Future of Nuclear Energy to 2030'' which said that "transparency and collaboration should be engendered by establishing a global nuclear safety network encompassing all stakeholders -relevant international organizations, governments, civil society and, most vitally, the nuclear industry".<ref name=louisef/><ref>Trevor Findlay. [http://www.cigionline.org/library/future-nuclear-energy-2030-and-its-implications-safety-security-and-nonproliferation-overvie The Future of Nuclear Energy to 2030 and its Implications for Safety, Security and Nonproliferation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616190800/http://www.cigionline.org/library/future-nuclear-energy-2030-and-its-implications-safety-security-and-nonproliferation-overvie |date=2011-06-16 }} February 4, 2010.</ref>
Findlay is also a professor at the [[Norman Paterson School of International Affairs]] and director of the [[Canadian Centre for Treaty Compliance]] at [[Carleton University]].<ref name=louisef>{{cite web |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/Nuclear+safety+world+problem/4513146/story.html |title=Nuclear safety is the world's problem |author=Louise Fréchette and Trevor Findlay |date=March 28, 2011 |work=Ottawa Citizen }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Louise Fréchette]] * [[Benjamin K. Sovacool]] * [[Amory Lovins]] * [[Mycle Schneider]] * [[Stephen Thomas (professor)]] * [[Renewable energy policy]] * [[Nuclear energy policy]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2014}} [[File:Urrbrae1.jpg|thumb|200px|alt=Aerial view of wetland surrounded by suburbs |Urrbrae Wetland]] The '''Urrbrae Wetland''' is a constructed urban [[wetland]] in the Australian state of [[South Australia]] located in the suburb of [[Urrbrae, South Australia|Urrbrae]] in the [[Adelaide|Adelaide metrolpolitan area]]. It was constructed to manage flood water from the nearby [[Adelaide Hills]] and has been developed to provide [[ecological]] and educational benefits. The wetland covers approximately 6 hectares<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=1492 |title=Urrbrae Wetland Facts |first= |last= |work=mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au |year=|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> of land previously part of [[Urrbrae Agricultural High School]]. The area of water is approximately 4 hectares and when full, contains approximately 13.5 million litres of water.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=1493 |title=The Function of the Wetland |first= |last=|work=mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au |year=|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref>
== Description == [[File:Urrbrae1a.jpg|thumb|200px|alt=Aerial view of wetland surrounded by suburbs |Wetland and Adelaide Hills]] The wetland consists of four ponds: the main pond, two [[sedimentation pond]]s and the farm dam. The main pond is clay lined and is designed to be kept filled to prevent drying out and cracking. The farm dam is synthetic lined and is used to top up the main dam when water levels are low. In an average year about 400 million litres of storm water passes through the wetland each year. When the wetland is full it contains about 13.5 million litres of water from a catchment of approximately 380 hectares.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=1492 |title=Urrbrae Wetland Facts |first= |last= |work=mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au |year=|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> Although it is not a true wetland, it serves a useful function in the cleansing of the stormwater via natural cleaning process including:
* The water flow is slowed down * Sand and other sediments fall to the bottom * Heavy metals, salts, bacteria et ‘stick’ onto the falling sand particles * Reeds, sedges and other plants along the shores filter out much of the salts and heavy metals.
Leaf litter, plastic bags and other debris is removed by trash removal systems at the entry to the sedimentation ponds to aid in cleansing of the water. The cleansed water then travels via storm water pipes to [[Brown Hill Creek]] and to the sea. This process is arranged and funded by the City of Mitcham. In 2011 construction began on pipes and facilities for some of the water to be pumped to tanks at the High School and used for watering grounds during summer months.
== History == In July 1993 the [[City of Mitcham]] and the [[Urrbrae Agricultural High School]] were independently investigating a wetland project. Mitcham Council was seeking to alleviate a long-standing flooding problem, while the school wanted to address regular flooding on its farmland and to broaden its environmental studies curriculum.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=1270 |title=Urrbrae Wetland |first= |last=|work=mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au |year=|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> Work on the project to construct the Urrbrae detention basin that would store the excess water commenced in June 1996 and finished in December 1996. It cost $1.2m, contributed by the City of Mitcham, the SA Department of Transport and the [Patawalonga River | Patawalonga] Catchment Water Management Board. The Education Department provided the land that was originally bequeathed to the State of South Australia for educational use by [[Peter Waite (philanthropist)|Peter Waite]], a prominent pastoralist of the early 20th century.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/waite-peter-993 |title=Biography - Peter Waite - Australian Dictionary of Biography |first= Marjorie|last=Findlay |work=adb.anu.edu.au |year=2011 |accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> In August 1997 the organisation, The Friends of the Urrbrae Wetland, was established, sponsored initially by the [[Rotary International|Rotary]] Club, Mitcham. The chief activity of the Friends is to establish, as far as possible, the native vegetation which existed prior to European settlement, and which is generally known as grey box woodland, [[Eucalyptus microcarpa]]. The Friends meet weekly for environmental improvement tasks including planting and weeding.
== Ecosystem == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:greyboxwoodland.jpg|thumb |alt=Grey box woodland surrounding lake with walkway |Grey box woodland and pond]] -->
===Plants=== [[File:Red wattlebird feeding off Grey Box flowers.jpg|thumb|Red wattlebird feeding off grey box flowers]] The native vegetation which existed prior to European settlement, and now found in the wetland, is generally known as grey box woodland. This ecological community is now classified as 'threatened' by the Australian Government Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/sprat/public/publicshowcommunity.pl?id=86 |title=Grey Box (Eucalyptus microcarpa) Grassy Woodlands and Derived Native Grasslands of South-eastern Australia |first= |last=|work=environment.gov.au |year=|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref>
====Grey box woodland====
The grey box woodland consists mainly of ''[[Eucalyptus microcarpa]]'', commonly known as the "grey box"<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.anbg.gov.au/cgi-bin/apni?taxon_id=1603 |title=Australian Plant Name Index |first= |last=|work=anbg.gov.au |year=|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> due to its bark colour, which was a dominant species on the southern Adelaide Plains. Over the years the Friends have planted over one hundred indigenous terrestrial and aquatic plant species to maximise diversity, habitat and serve as a resource for other revegetation projects.
For example, * Canopy plants: Grey box (''Eucalyptus microcarpa''), river red gum (''[[Eucalyptus camaldulensis]]''), South Australian blue gum (''[[Eucalyptus leucoxylon]]'')) and drooping sheoak (''[[Allocasuarina verticillata]]''), ''Callitris gracilis'' and native apricot * Shrubs including five different varieties of acacias or wattles, ''Bursaria spinosa'', sticky hop bush, ''Dodonaea viscosa'' * Under-story plants including several varieties of saltbrush, eutaxia, vittadinia daisies, lilies and many varieties of native grasses.
====Plants that grow well in the Wetland==== The plants listed below grow well at the Urrbrae Wetland as identified in March 2013.<ref>[http://www.mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=1491 Friends of Urrbrae Wetland] retrieved 15 April 2013</ref> {| style="width: 70%; height: 25px" border="0" |- | '''Botanic Name|| '''Common names |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Acacia acinacea]]|| Gold-dust wattle, round leaf wattle |- style="height: 20px;" | Acacia dodonaeifolia|| Sticky wattle |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Acacia paradoxa]]|| Kangaroo thorn |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Acacia pycnantha]]|| Golden wattle |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Acacia retinoides]] (swamp form)|| Swamp wattle |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Allocasuarina verticillata]]|| Drooping sheoak |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Arthropodium strictum]]|| Vanilla or chocolate lily |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Atriplex semibaccata]]|| Creeping saltbush, berry saltbush|| |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Austrodanthonia]] spp.|| Wallaby grass || |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Austrostipa]] spp.||Spear grasses including those listed below |- style="height: 20px;" | Austrostipa curticoma|| Short-crest spear grass |- style="height: 20px;" | Austrostipa elegantissima|| Feather spear grass elegant |- style="height: 20px;" | Austrostipa nodosa|| |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Billardiera cymosa]]|| Sweet apple-berry |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Bulbine bulbosa]]|| Bulbine-lily, native leek |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Bursaria spinosa]]|| Sweet bursaria, Christmas bush |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Callitris gracilis]] (formerly preissii)|| Southern cypress pine |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Calostemma purpureum]]|| Yellow or pink garland lily |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Carex]] spp.|| Tussock sedge, tall sedge |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Chloris truncata]]|| Windmill grass, star grass |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Chrysocephalum apiculatum]]|| Common everlasting |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Chrysocephalum semipapposum]]|| Clustered everlasting |- style="height: 20px;"| | [[Chrysocephalum semipapposum]]|| Clustered everlasting |- style="height: 20px;" | [[Cladium procerum]] || Leafy twig-rush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Clematis microphylla]]|| Old man’s beard |- style="height: 20px;" |Convolvulus remotus|| Australian bindweed |- style="height: 20px;" |Cullen australasicum|| Native scurf pea |- style="height: 20px;" |Cyperus gymnocaulos|| Spiny sedge, spiny flat sedge |- style="height: 20px;" |Cyperus vaginatus|| Flat sedge |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Dianella revoluta]]|| Black-anther flax lily |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Dianella brevicaulis]]|| Black-anther lily |- style="height: 20px;" |Dichanthium sericeum|| Queensland blue grass, silky blue grass |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Dodonaea viscosa]] sp. spatulata|| Giant hop bush, sticky hop bush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Einadia nutans]]|| Climbing saltbush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Enchylaena tomentosa]]|| Ruby saltbush, berry cottonbush |- style="height: 20px;" |Epilobium hirtigerum|| Willowherb |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Eucalyptus camaldulensis]]|| Flooded gum, river red gum, yarrah |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Eucalyptus leucoxylon]]|| Yellow gum, S.A. blue gum |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Eucalyptus microcarpa]]|| Grey box |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Eutaxia microphylla]]|| allee bush-pea or large leaf eutaxia |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Eutaxia diffusa]]|| Spreading mallee pea |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Ficinia nodosa]]|| Knobby club-rush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Geranium retrorsum]]|| Common cranes bill, native geranium |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Goodenia albiflora]]|| White goodenia |- style="height: 20px;" |Goodenia amplexans || Clasping goodenia |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Hardenbergia violacea]]|| False sarsaparilla, native lilac, coral pea |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Juncus kraussii]]|| Sea rush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Juncus pallidus]]|| Pale rush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Juncus subsecundus]]|| Finger rush |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Kennedia prostrata]]|| Scarlet runner, running postman |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Leptospermum lanigerum]]|| Silky tea-tree |- style="height: 20px;" |Lomandra densiflora|| Pointed mat-rush |- style="height: 20px;" |Lomandra multiflora sp. dura|| Many-flowered mat-rush |- style="height: 20px;" |Lycopus australis|| Australian gypsywort |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Lythrum hyssopifolia]]|| Hyssop loosestrife, lesser loosestrife |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Malva behriana]]|| Native hollyhock, Australian hollyhock |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Myoporum viscosum]]|| Sticky boobialla |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Olearia ramulosa]]|| Twiggy daisy bush, oily bush |- style="height: 20px;" |Persicaria decipiens|| Slender knotweed |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Persicaria lapathifolia]]|| Pale knotweed |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Phragmites australis]]|| Common reed, cane-grass |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Pittosporum angustifolium]]|| Native apricot, butterbush |- style="height: 20px;" |Pseudognaphalium luteo-album|| Cudweed, Jersey cudweed |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Ranunculus lappaceus]]|| Common buttercup, native buttercup |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Rubus parvifolius]]|| Small-leaf raspberry, native raspberry |- style="height: 20px;" |Senecio hypoleucus|| Pale groundsel |- style="height: 20px;" |Senecio quadridentatus|| Cotton groundsel |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Themeda triandra]]|| Kangaroo grass |- style="height: 20px;" |Vittadinia blackii|| Western New Holland daisy |- style="height: 20px;" |Vittadinia cuneata|| Fuzzy New Holland daisy |- style="height: 20px;" |Vittadinia gracilis|| Woolly New Holland daisy |- style="height: 20px;" |[[Wahlenbergia stricta]]|| Austral bluebell, tall bluebell |- style="height: 20px;" |}
====Aquatic animals====
Water based animals include four frog species and over fifty macro invertebrate species, [[Australian rainbowfish|Murray River rainbowfish]] and [[common yabby]]. [[File:Cherax_destructor_(Cyan_yabby).jpg#file|thumb|alt=Small lobster-like under water|Common yabby]]
====Birds==== [[File:Pacific Black Duck jun08.jpg|thumb|200px|alt=Grey duck swimming in smooth water|Pacific black duck]] The permanent water in the wetland, its adjacent habitats and a reliable feed source, have attracted many species of waterbirds to this site. Commonly seen birds are [[Pacific black duck]] hybrids, [[Australian wood duck]], [[Australasian grebe]], [[Eurasian coot]]. Some rarely seen birds are [[sacred kingfisher]], and the [[little lorikeet]].
With the presence of maturing nectar bearing and insect attracting flora, an increasing number of bush birds can also be seen in the different seasons. For example, when the eucalpytus are flowering the [[New Holland honeyeater]], [[musk lorikeet]] and [[rainbow lorikeet]] are frequent visitors. Breeding of some species is occurring in the Wetland, including the, [[dusky moorhen]], [[Eurasian coot]], [[Australasian grebe]], [[clamorous reed warbler]], [[magpie-lark]], [[willie wagtail]], [[crested pigeon]] and [[spotted turtle dove]].
== Education ==
===School and tertiary education===
The wetland has a classroom with laboratory facilities and visual aids providing a major learning centre for the Urrbrae Agricultural High School and TAFE (Technical and Further Education) students on the nearby school campus. The school funds the position of a Science Teacher-Manager permanently on site. It is also used by other schools and community groups who come to the centre to learn about the role of wetland. Each year about 10,000 students visit the wetland.
===Community education===
The Friends of the Urrbrae Wetland offer two Open Days a year which include a talk and guided walk, to which the general public is invited. A focus of these talks and guided walks is the reestablishment of the Grey Box Woodland.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Portal|Wetlands}} * [http://www.urrbraewetlandlc.org/index.html Urrbrae Wetland Learning Centre] * [http://www.mitchamcouncil.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=1491 Friends of Urrbrae Wetland ] * [http://birdie.180pi.net/urrbrae_wetland The Birdie Project] * [http://www.urrbraehs.sa.edu.au/Wetland/Wetland.htm Urrbrae Wetland, Urrbrae Agricultural High School] * [http://www.abc.net.au/local/videos/2012/09/20/3594448.htm?site=adelaide ABC Television overview of the wetland Sept 2012, video 3 min ]

revision.comment: cleanup

Incorrect English "in the clear" (= not guilty) corrected to "in clear" (= not coded, from French "en clair") - I've found the same error (twice) in the article on the Zimmermann telegram, which may have been written by the same person~~~~
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=May 2011}} Codes and ciphers were used extensively in [[World War I]]. The decoding by British Naval intelligence of the [[Zimmermann telegram]] helped bring the United States into the war.
[[Trench code]]s were used by field armies of most of the combatants (Americans, British, French, German) in World War I.
The most commonly used codes were simple substitution codes. More important messages generally used mathematical encryption for extra security, though. The use of these codes required the distribution of codebooks to military personnel, which proved to be a security liability since these books could be stolen by enemy forces.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lerner|first1=Adrienne|title=World War I|url=http://www.faqs.org/espionage/Vo-Z/World-War-I.html|website=Espionage Information: Encyclopedia of Espionage, Intelligence, and Security|publisher=Advameg, Inc.|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref>
==Britain== [[File:Ztel2.jpg|thumb|right|Zimmermann telegram as decoded by Room 40]] British decrypting was carried out in [[Room 40]] by the Royal Navy and in [[MI1]] by British Military (Army) Intelligence. * [[Zimmermann telegram]] * [[Arthur Zimmermann]] * [[MI1]] British Military (Army) Intelligence * [[Room 40]] Royal Navy (Britain) * [[Alastair Denniston]] Room 40 * [[James Alfred Ewing]] Room 40, first head * [[Nigel de Grey]] Room 40 * [[William R. Hall]] ‘Blinker’ Hall, Room 40, second head * [[Dilly Knox]] Room 40 * [[Oliver Strachey]] MI1 * [[William Montgomery (cryptographer)]] Room 40 * [[Playfair cipher]]
==Russia== * [[Ernst Fetterlein]] was in the Tzarist Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs from 1896, and solved (among others) German, Austrian and British codes. He was eventually made chief cryptographer with the rank of admiral. With the Russian Revolution in 1917 he fled to Britain, and was recruited to Room 40 in June 1918 to work on Austrian, Bolshevik, and Georgian codes. * The Russians used an overcomplicated version of the [[Vigenère Cipher]]. It was broken within three days by Austro-Hungarian cryptanalyst [[Hermann Pokorny]].
==France== The French Army employed [[Georges Painvin]], and [[Étienne Bazeries]] who came out of retirement, on German ciphers. Due to their prewar activities, the French were more prepared than any other nation involved in the war to decode German radiograms. At the beginning of the war, France had eight intercept stations: Maubeuge, Verdun, Toul, Epinal, Belfort, Lille, Rheims, and Besançon. During the war, they set up many more stations, including one in the Eiffel Tower. According to Colonel Cartier of the War Ministry, France intercepted over 100,000,000 words from German radiograms during the course of the war.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kahn|first1=David|title=The Codebreakers|date=1967|publisher=Scribner}}</ref>
* The [[Tableau de Concordance]] was the main French diplomatic cipher.
==Germany and Austria== Germany and Austria intercepted Russian radio traffic, although German success at the [[Battle of Tannenberg (1914)]] was due to interception of messages between the Russian commanders in clear.
The German [[Abhorchdienst]], a code-breaking bureau composed mainly of mathematicians, was established in 1916.
The Germans had specific regulations regarding which kinds of codes and ciphers could be used under given circumstances. Within three kilometers of the front lines, known as the danger zone, all communications were required to be in a code known as the three-number code. This was the only code or cipher permitted. Behind this danger zone, another code known as the three-letter code was allowed to be used. Communications between divisions, corps, and army headquarters were done with the ADFGVX cipher.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Friedman|first1=William|title=Solving German Codes in World War I|date=1977|publisher=Aegean Park Press}}</ref>
The ADFGX and [[ADFGVX]] field ciphers were a modified [[Polybius square | polybius system]] with single order double columnar transposition and frequent key change, with letters optimized for Morse. It was later broken by the famous French cryptanalyst [[Georges Painvin]]. The breaking of the ADFGX cipher by Painvin was the second time during the war that cryptanalysis played a major role in shaping events (the first being the interception and cracking of the Zimmerman Telegram). By breaking the cipher, the French were able to decode an intercepted message about the forwarding of munitions for a German offensive, letting the French know where and when the offensive would occur, and thus allowing them to stop it. This message became known as "The Radiogram of Victory."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kahn|first1=David|title=In Memoriam: Georges-Jean Painvain|journal=Cryptologica|volume=6|issue=2|pages=120–127}}</ref>
==United States== [[Herbert Yardley]] began as a code clerk in the State Department. After the outbreak of war he became the head of the cryptographic section of Military Intelligence Section [[Black Chamber|(MI-8)]]<ref name=Codebreakers>{{cite book|last=Kahn|first=David|title=The Codebreakers: the Story of Secret Writing|year=1996|publisher=Scribner|location=New York|isbn=0-684-83130-9|page=352|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SEH_rHkgaogC&pg=PA352&lpg=PA352#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and was with the American Expeditionary Force in World War I as a Signals Corps cryptologic officer in France. He later headed the Cipher Bureau, a new cryptanalysis group started in 1919, immediately after World War I, and funded jointly by the State Department and the US Army.
Some American cryptography in World War I was done at the ''Riverbank Laboratory'' where [[Elizebeth Friedman]], [[William F. Friedman]] and [[Agnes Meyer Driscoll]] worked. The ''Riverbank Laboratory'', Chicago was privately owned by Colonel George Fabyan.
The US Navy used the cryptographic code [[A-1 (code)|A-1]]. The US Navy cryptanalysis group, [[OP-20-G]], was also started after World War I (in 1922).
The US also started employing Indian [[code talker]]s in World War I, initially with members of the Cherokee and Choctaw tribes.
==See also== {{portal|World War I}} * [[World War I]] * [[Cryptography]] * [[History of cryptography]] * [[World War II cryptography]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links== * {{Library resources about|onlinebooks=yes}}
